DOC.HEAD: Israelis Destroy Two Guerrilla Posts in Lebanon, 9 Killed
By RODEINA KENAAN
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: Israeli warplanes destroyed a Communist Party command post south of Beirut Tuesday, hours after paratroopers backed by tanks and air cover wiped out another Communist base in southeastern Lebanon. Police said nine people were killed and 26 wounded in the two attacks. In Beirut, the Lebanese army defused a car rigged with 165 pounds of explosives near Prime Minister Salim Hoss' office 30 minutes before it was set to go off, police said. ``A bloodbath has been averted,'' said a police spokesman. Hoss, a Sunni Moslem, was at home five blocks away when the bomb was discovered and did not appear to be the target, the spokesman said on condition of anonymity. Police said at least seven people were killed and 23 wounded in the five-minute air raid that wrecked the two-story Communist Party headquarters in the coastal town of Rmeile, 20 miles south of the capital. The building took at least two direct rocket hits as six Phantom F-4 fighter-bombers attacked it. Rescuers searched the wreckage for more victims late Tuesday. Reporters heard moans and screams from beneath the debris. Among those killed was Communist commander codenamed Abu Rabei, who just before his death screamed for his 22-year-old daughter, still buried in the ruins. In Jerusalem, the Israeli military command said its warplanes returned to their bases. It said the Communists had organized and launched attacks on Israeli forces and the South Lebanon Army, an Israeli-backed Lebanese militia. Police said two other Communist guerrillas were killed and three wounded as Israeli paratroopers earlier destroyed the Communist base at Nabi Safi, in the foothills of Mount Hermon 7{ miles north of the zone Israel occupies in south Lebanon. The two-hour assault was the Israeli army's heaviest ground operation in Lebanon since an assault against the Syrian-backed Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command Dec. 9, 1988. The attack force of 100 commandos advanced from the border enclave, occupied by Israel since 1982, in four tanks and eight armored personnel carriers behind a massive artillery barrage, police reported. The attackers stormed through the villages of Kfar Meshki and Lebbaya in the eastern Bekaa Valley after two helicopter gunships blasted the villages with eight rockets, destroying many houses, the spokesman said. Forty other paratroopers were then dropped by helicopters in Nabi Safa, where they blew up the Communists' two-story command post, the spokesman added. The Israeli military said their side suffered no casualties. But a Communist Party statement in Beirut said ``the enemy suffered heavy losses in lives and ammunition at the hands of our heroes who fought hand-to-hand to repulse the attack.'' The villages have long been used by the Communists and other leftist Lebanese and Palestinian guerrilla factions allied with Syria to attack the Israeli-held zone. Also Tuesday, police said heavy artillery duels raged Tuesday in south Lebanon about 15 miles west of Nabi Safa between the Iranian-backed Hezbollah, or Party of God, and the Syrian-allied Amal. The two militias also clashed with machine guns and rocket-propelled grenades in the Shiite slums of Hay el-Lija in west Beirut after midday. There were no reports of casualties in Beirut. Police have reported at least 38 people killed and 150 wounded in the south since Saturday in a renewed power struggle between the rival groups for control of Lebanon's 1.2 million Shiites, the country's largest sect.
